propositions.text: The narrative begins with a description of instinct and desire as a boiling cauldron with irrational energy, driven by the pleasure principle.
This energy urgently seeks an outlet, pursuing satisfaction.
A man is depicted in the city center on March 20, 2002, holding a large gift box, appearing hurried and happy, anticipating a meeting with his beloved.
The atmosphere in the city is tense due to recent disturbing events.
A news report announces a police investigation into a serial killer case, dubbed the 'couple skinning killer'.
The report states that the police are collaborating with FBI experts and believe the case is close to being solved.
Citizens are warned about the killer's potential activity and advised not to go out alone at night.
A coffee shop owner expresses frustration over lost customers due to the crime and offers a free coffee to Martha, whose expected friend has not shown up.
He advises Martha, a pretty blonde, to be careful.
Martha is distressed as her fiancé is not answering her calls, especially on her birthday.
The news broadcast adds to her unease.
The first murder case occurred on March 1st, with two bodies found the next morning, their faces stripped of skin.
The bodies were discovered in different parts of the city, about 50 km apart.
The male victim had his genitals removed, and the female victim had an iron rod inserted into her lower body.
The word 'mask' was written in blood on the walls behind the bodies.
This level of violence and body mutilation in a serial killer case is described as unique and rare.
Another pair of bodies was found on March 12th, treated in the same manner, further troubling the police.
The killer's modus operandi involves shooting the victims before disposing of the bodies, making it difficult to determine if it's one or two killers.
The victims have no apparent connection, and the pattern is always one male and one female, suggesting indiscriminate killing.
This has led to a state of quiet dread in the city, and the police are intensely investigating the 'couple mask killer' case.
Martha regrets refusing the coffee shop owner's offer of a ride home, feeling fear as it's late and raining heavily.
She reflects on her fiancé's earlier joke about the killer being a taxi driver.
Martha calls her home and reaches an answering machine, feeling despair.
The city of Portland, where she has lived for four years, now feels strange and eerie due to the rain.
While sheltering, a man on the second floor of a building observes someone with an umbrella passing below and smiles.
He mutters to himself about the '5th' and what comes next.
A young man approaches Martha, offering her a ride home, seeming nervous and shy.
He shows her his student ID and explains he was at the library researching recent events.
Martha hesitantly accepts his offer, feeling that refusing might not offer much more safety.
During their walk, Martha asks his name, and he replies 'Diate'.
She tells him her name is Martha.
Diate asks if she was waiting for her boyfriend, and Martha explains he didn't come and she is worried about him.

Diate tries to reassure her, sharing his father's history as a police officer who believed in justice and his own desire to be a police officer, which was hindered by his premature birth and poor health.
He enjoys researching cases and mentions the 'Bellflower' serial rape-murder case in England.
Diate stops walking and compliments Martha's appearance, making her nervous.
He then laughs, claiming it was a joke, and urges them to hurry.
Martha receives a call from her landlord, Anthony, who sounds distressed.
Anthony starts to tell her something about Eli, causing Martha extreme fear.
Diate seizes Martha's arm, revealing his sinister intent, and laughs maniacally.
Martha struggles and searches her bag for a small bottle.
A loud sound is heard, followed by smoke. The man collapses and dies.
Martha screams and collapses, dropping a dark object.
The landlord's voice is heard on the dropped phone, stating that Eli is in critical condition at the hospital.
About half an hour later, a black Buick arrives, and a man in a long coat exits, examining a fruit shop's window and touching it with a gloved hand.
He then takes something else from the car and drives away.
A 10-year-old boy emerges and looks at the shop window.
The words 'mask will be back soon' are written on the large glass window.
Chapter 2 begins on March 21, 2002, with Old Samran preparing for work.
He examines disturbing crime scene photos of victims without faces, one male with removed genitals and the other female with a steel rod inserted.
These photos are stored in a locked drawer.
Samran reflects on his age and upcoming retirement, acknowledging the changing times.
He remembers his old partner who taught him a lot and regrets that his new partner arrived too late to work together extensively.
He heads to Levin Street, responding to a report of the word 'mask' being seen on a shop window, considering it a potential crime scene even if it's a prank.
Samran contemplates the fading of passion with age but the strengthening of resilience.
He avoids making assumptions on the way to a scene to maintain objectivity.
He muses on human nature and psychology, recalling his interesting work with a British colleague named Paul.
He feels a deep sense of identity and satisfaction in his 40 years as a police officer.
Arriving at Levin Street, Samran meets his new partner, Carlos, and other officers at the scene.
He notes Carlos's youthful energy, reminiscent of a movie character.
Seeing the words 'mask will be back soon' written in what appears to be blood on a shop window, Samran feels overwhelmed, despite his experience with crime.
The large size of the writing suggests it's meant to be seen.
He wonders if the previous murders were just the beginning.
Samran instructs the crime scene photographers and requests support and cleaning supplies to remove the writing to avoid public panic.
He interviews an elderly man who reported the 'mask' writing.
The man states his dog, Mark, alerted him to the writing, which he initially dismissed as a prank.
The dog's persistence led him to investigate and realize the significance, remembering the radio broadcast.
The man and his dog went out at 5 AM, and he notified the police around 5:15 AM.
Samran and Carlos question residents about unusual activity the previous night.
They learn that the fruit shop owner, Mark, closed early, unusual for him.
They also hear about a peculiar incident involving the owner and a dog also named Mark.
Carlos expresses doubt about the effectiveness of questioning residents, but Samran insists on the importance of the investigative process, recalling an anecdote from his former partner.
The anecdote emphasizes that the process of pursuing a result is more important than the result itself.
At the Kendall Psychological Clinic, Dr. Kendall inquires about cleaning services, receiving a positive response.
Ms. Carlisle, a single mother, arrives with her son Eddie and expresses her anxiety to Dr. Kendall.
She is concerned because Eddie went out the previous night and claims to have seen a 'black man'.
She fears the police will question Eddie and attract the killer.
Dr. Kendall tries to reassure her, suggesting Eddie might have dreamt it and offering to help her find another psychologist if she decides to move.
Ms. Carlisle reveals that Eddie seemed to anticipate the police's arrival and that they weren't in uniform.
Old John recounts how his dog, Mark, led him to Dr. Waller's clinic, where he befriended the young Chinese psychologist.
He describes Dr. Waller's cooking as delicious and authentic Chinese.
Dr. Waller uses a 'little cat family' sand tray game with Eddie to understand his perception of family dynamics.
He asks Eddie to identify the 'black cat' and its actions.
Eddie describes the black cat writing 'mask is back' on a glass cup.
Carlos is frustrated by the lack of leads in the mask killer case, facing immense pressure from the public and media.
He discusses a separate case of a victim found dead in a hospital after being beaten, with only a work ID remaining.
The conversation touches upon the FBI and their perceived portrayal in media, contrasting it with the reality of law enforcement officers.
Lucas is thinking about the single mother he encountered earlier when his phone rings.
He is called to room 205 to attend to a woman reporting a murder.
Samran, following Old John's remark, goes to Dr. Waller's clinic, contemplating the nature of the psychologist.

hierarchy.structure: The document is structured into chapters, with a clear narrative progression. Chapter 1 introduces the central mystery and characters, Chapter 2 delves deeper into the investigation with experienced detectives and introduces a new element (the clinic), and Chapter 3 continues the investigation and introduces more characters and their backstories. Chapter 4 focuses on psychological analysis and the unfolding of the investigation through different perspectives.
